item.title: Analysis | America’s doughnut capital. Can we stop at just one?
item.description: No country loves fried dough more than the United States. But is America split by a hidden doughnut divide? We investigate.

item.title: Supreme Risk: An Interactive Guide to Rights the Supreme Court Could Take Away
item.description: Most rights are based in statute, but dozens — such as rights to same-sex marriage, search warrants and Miranda warnings — are based on judicial rulings that the Supreme Court can overturn and that current justices have questioned some aspect of.

item.title: Journalists at country’s largest newspaper chain will walk off the job
item.description: Hundreds of staffers at Gannett newspapers across seven states are protesting their company’s leadership and job cuts.

item.title: Pork-pocalypse now? In wake of Supreme Court ruling and 2016 vote, pork prices could soar in Mass. - The Boston Globe
item.description: A 2016 animal welfare ballot measure that would prohibit most US pork from being sold in Massachusetts could finally take effect as soon as next month. And pork purveyors here say that means prices are about to pop.

item.title: From the editor: Sonoma County trans student-athlete’s story is not ours to tell
item.description: The national firestorm that ignited last week over a Sonoma County transgender student-athlete is bullying, plain and simple, says Richard A. Green, executive editor of The Press Democrat.

item.title: As wildfire smoke worsens public health, government watchdog calls EPA response 'ad hoc'
item.description: Congressional investigators say the use of a regulatory loophole to erase smoke pollution from the official record is on the rise.

item.title: Gannett is experiencing a mass exodus among top execs. Here’s who has left. - Poynter
I Know One Way the Supreme Court Got to How It Is. I Watched It Happen for Years.
item.description: There are solutions we could begin right now.

item.title: Eat more beans. Please.
item.description: Beans are high in protein, efficient to grow, and can even improve soil health. They cost less than conventional or new plant-based meats, and they’re increasingly getting attention among foodies.

item.title: Unpacking the Myths of Drilling in MMA, BJJ, and Kickboxing: Understanding Ecological Dynamics
item.description: The world of martial arts has been long dominated by the belief that repetitive drilling leads to perfected techniques and muscle memory. However, this conventional wisdom is often contradicted by research and practices in the dynamic and complex sports of MMA, BJJ, and Kickboxing. In this article, we'll delve into the key myths surrounding drilling and explore the ecological dynamics that shape the way we learn and perform in these sports. What the end of the COVID public health emergency means in Massachusetts
item.description: After more than three years, COVID public health emergencies at the federal level and in Massachusetts come to an end Thursday. Here's what will change with testing, masking, vaccination and more.

item.description: C’mon, Denis Villeneuve, give us our giant philosophical worm king

item.title: Opinion | Pickleball is the worst
item.description: Any game you can take up after breakfast and be pretty good at by lunch is not a sport. And it isn't even great exercise.

item.title: Analysis | America’s learned helplessness on guns
item.description: The debate over how to address gun violence is between doing something and doing nothing.

item.title: Electrify everything (in my house)
Analysis | The low cost (for a rich person) of sponsoring a Supreme Court justice
item.description: America's wealth gap makes it trivial for billionaires to cover whoever's bills they want.
